lexUnit.name: insult.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: a statement intended to be insulting

sentence.text: Then , after that humiliation , he had added insult to injury by saying she 'd be perfectly safe with him !
You add insult to my injury and I will have no more of it . "
Her foul-mouthed old mother was also to be seen at the school ` meetings " , shouting about the bottoms , while children hurled abuse and insult and accusations at one another .
And I ca n't watch football any more because of the way white fans shout racist insults at the black players .
He exchanged insults with the dog in the wine barrel and got a kick in the ribs from his master .
This was all unsuccessful , so he tried personal insults .
He saw it as a deliberate insult to the Church , a kind of Satanic Cross on the hill .
Cuban President Fidel Castro in his opening speech denounced the continuing US embargo against Cuba as " genocide and an insult to humanity " .
The first of these statements was such an insult to my intelligence that I wanted to punch Mr Kinnock on the nose , and the second so downright outrageous that I wanted to do something worse .
To remove his statue in such a disrespectful manner was an insult not only to Mao Zedong but also the Communist Party .
She , for her part , was of the opinion that she did not object to Ivan 's insults at all .
The battling couple have frequently traded insults in books and through magazine interviews .
To make such a parallel was an insult to these young people who considered themselves more sophisticated than the Red Guard generation .
Jake had been hurling these same insults at her now for years , and by now she ought to be totally immune to them .
